data.text: Contents
Purpose
This policy is designed to:
Ensure that all Consultants and SAS Doctors have a transparent, current, signed
o ff, job plan with agreed objectives that is reviewed at least annually
B ring consistency and transparency to job planning across the Trust
D escribe the circumstances when variations might be appropriate
Provide an annual timetable for job planning
Introduction
To make job planning a better instrument for doctors / dentists and managers to provide high quality care, the job planning process should be:
Undertaken in a spirit of collaboration and cooperation
Completed in good time and preparation of the following financial year and or service improvements / change
Reflective of the professionalism as expected by the GMC
Focused on agreed measurable outcomes that benefit and is focussed on patient centred services and improves overall quality of care and patient
experience
Consistent with the objectives and culture of the NHS, the organisation, division, teams and individuals
Transparent, fair and honest
Fully agreed and not imposed
Flexible and responsive to changing service needs during each job plan year
Job planning should not be carried out in isolation. It should form part of a dynamic, patient-focused process which incorporates organisational, team and individual objectives.

A job plan can be described in simple terms as a prospective, professional agreement that sets out the duties, responsibilities, accountabilities and objectives of the doctor / dentist and the support and resources provided by the employer for the coming year.
This Policy:
Is based on the Terms and Conditions for Consultants (England) 2003 and SAS Doctors (2008) and the Guide to Consultant Job Planning agreed by the BMA and NHS Employers 2011
Sets out the Trust principles for Job Planning and responsibilities for the process
Scope
This policy applies to all Consultant and SAS medical staff working at Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust.
Medical and Dental T&Cs state that the criteria to be referred to annually for pay progression purposes are that the Consultant has:
Made every reasonable effort to meet the time and service commitments in the Job Plan, including participating fully in the job planning process
Participated satisfactorily in the appraisal process
Adhered to Trust and personal objectives linked to the job plan, or where this is not achieved, made every reasonable effort to do so

Taken up any offer to undertake Additional Programmed Activities that the Trust has made to the Consultant or SAS Doctor in accordance with Schedule 6 of the Terms and Conditions, unless another doctor agrees to do the work
Met the standards of conduct governing the relationship between private practice and NHS commitments set out in Schedule 9 of the Terms and Conditions
Undertaken the appropriate Statutory and Mandatory Training
Principles
Job Planning process will be undertaken with professionalism, honesty and transparency by all involved.
Job planning will be prospective and agreed in line with service needs and aligned to finance and within budget.
The job plan must be aligned with the Trust objectives and with the service business plan.
Consultant and SAS doctors will be remunerated on the basis of an agreed and fully signed off job plan.
The Trust will adopt a consistent and fair approach based on the principles set out in this policy.
The Trust will work in partnership with Consultants and SAS Doctors to agree Job Plans.

A full-time consultant contract (under the 2003 contract) comprises a 10 PA job plan which may have further, agreed, additional PAs (APAs), usually up to a maximum of  PAs. The job plans of all full time consultants will include a minimum of 1.5 Core SPAs and Specialty Doctors, Staff and Associate Specialist Grade (SASG) will include a minimum of 1 Core SPA to deliver the requirements of revalidation and basic clinical management (such as attending departmental management and clinical governance meetings). Further SPA allocation will pertain to specific additional roles and activities as set out in Appendix 1. Certain SPA allocations may be funded from external sources.
Direct Clinical Care (DCC) time allocation in job plans should be delivered in an annualised manner over  weeks, ensuring 52 weeks of sufficient service cover over the whole year.

If SPA activity is cancelled for other activities, that SPA should be reinstated at another mutually agreed appropriate time. Unless there are extenuating circumstances this reinstatement should occur within 6 weeks of the cancellation.

The Consultant contract and BMA guidance state that a full time Consultant will typically undertake 2.5 SPAs per week. Therefore 2.5 is neither a minimum nor a maximum; neither is it an allowance. Each full time consultant will receive a minimum core SPA of 1.5. Anything above will be agreed with the Clinical Lead in line with service needs.

Core SPA will be a defined entity on the electronic job plan and will reflect all the activities in Appendix 1.To ensure value of this time for both the doctor and the Trust it must be allocated in blocks of time not less than 1 hour (0.25 PA).

It is important that part time doctors receive sufficient SPA allocation for activities to support revalidation. Where the part time doctor is not employed by another Trust, they are entitled to a pro-rata SPA allocation to support revalidation as set out in the table below. The minimum allocation is 0.5 SPA.
For example, a doctor with a commitment to MSE of 3 DCC PAs will receive 1 SPA to support revalidation (Total contract of employment will be 4 PAs).
Consultants
Speciality Doctors

For doctors who raise concerns with regards to their health it is important that the doctor and their clinical manager, with advice from the Trust's Health & Wellbeing Service, ensure the job plan takes into account any reasonable adjustments that are required.

if the clinicians circumstances change or additional activity is required, which would have the effect of altering the doctor's DCC or SPA allocation (if a research project ends or the doctor takes on an educational supervisor role, for example) then an additional job plan review will take place within four weeks of either side's request for review

Where the value of an on call supplement is to be changed with agreement with the doctor concerned, this change will be effective immediately. Any changes to the payment of on call supplements should be made following an analysis of the rota.

Where a PA allocation for unpredictable work arising out of on call is to be changed with the agreement of the doctor concerned, this change will be effective immediately. Any such changes should be made following a review of the rota which may include a monitoring exercise to document on-call activity.

Where no agreement has been reached with the doctor concerned in relation to changes to the value of their on call availability supplement or PA allocation for unpredictable work arising out of an on call, the doctor can proceed to the mediation and appeal process in accordance with this policy. No change to job plan or payment should be implemented until the mediation and appeal process has been completed.

If an agreed activity cannot be carried out due to circumstances outside of the doctor's control, for example due to a last minute cancellation of a procedure slot or failure of equipment or IT systems, then it is expected that he/she will undertake other NHS work in this time according to the needs of the service in line with local departmental processes. The service manager should be advised of the change in DCC activity.
Roles and Responsibilities
Chief Medical Officer – responsible for oversight of job planning compliance across all sites.
Site Medical Directors - Where there is failure to agree a Job Plan at specialty level a site Medical Director is responsible for the mediation and appeals process in accordance with appendix
Divisional / Directorate managers have responsibility for ensuring Job Planning takes place within their divisions.
The Consultant or SAS Doctor with appropriate support, must ensure they have an up to date job plan which is signed off annually.
Equality and Diversity

Mid and South Essex Foundation trust is committed to providing equality of opportunity for all present and potential members of staff, and aims to ensure that no existing or potential employee receives less favourable treatment on the grounds of sex, sexual orientation, race, colour, nationality, ethnic origin, religion, marital status, carer status, socio economic background, employment status, political affiliation and trade union membership, age or disability, or is disadvantaged by conditions or requirements which cannot be shown to be justifiable.
The principles of equality and diversity should be applied within the Job Planning process so all members of staff are treated fairly and equally.
Programmed Activities

A Programmed Activity (PA) is a scheduled period, nominally equivalent to four hours, during which a doctor undertakes Contractual Services. The 2003 Consultant contract is based upon a full time work commitment of 10 Programmed Activities (PAs) per week.

Supporting professional activities (SPA) are an essential part of the work of consultants and SAS doctors. They should be directly relevant to the individual doctor and to achieving the objectives of the Trust, underpinning and improving direct clinical activity.

SPA should be specified in the Job Plan and usually take place in core hours, some flexibility with respect to time and place where appropriate and reasonable with focus on achievement of agreed outcomes. This will mutually agree with your Clinical Lead / Clinical Director. To ensure SPA time is productive it should be taken in blocks of 1 hour or more.

Detailed definitions of PAs – direct clinical care (DCC), supporting professional activities (SPA), additional NHS responsibilities (ANR), external duties (ED) and emergency work - are shown in Appendix 1. This is to ensure that the process is transparent and applied in a consistent manner across the Trust.

Each 4 hours of work has a value of one PA, unless it has been mutually agreed between the Consultant or SAS Doctor and the Trust to undertake the work in premium time, in which case each PA equates to 3 hours. Premium time is classified as any time that falls outside of the hours 07:00 to 19:00 Monday to Friday and any time on a Saturday or Sunday, or public holiday. Programmed activities may be programmed as blocks of 4 hours or in smaller units where approved as appropriate.
PAs above  per week (Additional Programmed Activities) are temporary and can be removed by either party with 3 months' notice (Please refer to Appendix 1 for more detail).
Where a Consultant or SAS Doctor works across more than one Specialty or organisation this should be reflected in the Job Plan and agreed in partnership with relevant stakeholders.
On call, please refer to schedule 5 and 8 of Terms & Conditions – Consultants (England) 2003 and Schedule 6 and 9 of the Terms & Conditions of Service Specialty Doctors – England (2008) (SAS TCS)
Travel time

Where Consultants or SAS Doctors spend time on more than one site during the course of a day, time spent travelling between sites will be counted in PA time. All travel associated with clinical activity should be recorded as DCC time and travel associated with non-clinical activity should be recorded as either Supporting Professional Activities (SPA) or Additional NHS Responsibilities as appropriate. Appendix 2 outlines the standard agreed travel time for common journeys.

Excess travel is defined as time spent travelling between home and a working site other than the Consultant or SAS Doctor's main place of work, after deducting the time normally spent travelling between home and main place of work.

Travelling time between a Consultant or SAS Doctor's main place of work and home or private practice premises is not to be regarded as working time, except for Travel to and from work for NHS emergencies as per Schedule  of the Terms & Conditions – Consultants (England) 2003 and Schedule 13 of the Terms & Conditions of Service Specialty Doctors – England (2008)”
Private Practice - Fee-paying services

The provision of services for private patients should not prejudice the interest of NHS patients or disrupt NHS services. With the exception of the need to provide emergency care, agreed NHS commitments will take precedence over private work. Even in the case of emergencies every effort should be made for the consultant to arrange appropriate consultant cover for NHS patients and appropriate handover takes place. NHS facilities, staff and services may only be used for private practice with the prior agreement of the NHS employer.
All fee-paying and private work should be explicitly discussed during the job planning meeting. Fee-paying and private work must take place in accordance with the following principles:

Consultants must demonstrate that they are acting in accordance with the code on private practice and Schedules 8 and 9 of the Terms & Conditions – Consultants (England) 2003. SAS doctors must demonstrate that they are acting in accordance with Schedule 7 of the Terms and Conditions (Speciality Doctors 2008).
For consultants on the pre-2003 contract, paragraphs 40 – 43 of the Terms & Conditions of Service NHS Medical & Dental Staff (England) 2002 apply.

Private practice must be clearly identified in a consultant's job plan, including specifying the site, day and time of the private activity, whether these activities are undertaken in the Trust or elsewhere, and even if it is in another hospital and even if it is “out of hours” including at weekends.

The work should not attract double payment: that is, all such work should be either undertaken outside the hours of the doctor's NHS contract and if it is carried out on site it should be clearly identified within a consultant's job plan as time for private work that is not funded or remunerated by the NHS.

There should be no disruption to a doctor's contracted PAs. In accordance with Schedule 8 paragraph 5 of the Terms & Conditions – Consultants (England) 2003, or with Schedule 9 paragraph 3 of the Terms & Conditions of Service Specialty Doctors – England (2008) (SAS TCS).

Fee paying Services (detailed in Schedule 10) are services that are not part of Contractual or Consequential Services and not reasonably incidental to them. The provisions governing them are detailed in Schedule 11. Such activities should have been agreed in advance with the Clinical Manager.

Doctors can retain fees for work done in their own time, or during annual or unpaid leave, providing it does not jeopardise the quality of, or their availability for, contracted NHS work (such as on call duties) and the requirements of the WTD.

For any consultant wishing to undertake private practice, Schedule 6 of the Terms & Conditions – Consultants (England) 2003” https://www.nhsemployers.org/pay-pensions-and-reward/medical- staff/consultants-and-dental-consultants
Effective Job Planning
Team job planning

10.2.1 Individual job planning will often be made easier if it is preceded by the agreement of joint team objectives. The delivery of activities is quantified and planned across a team of doctors over the whole year (52 weeks). Once the team job plan is agreed, each member of that team must actively participate in individual job planning so that their contribution to the team is clear and transparent to the clinical service unit members.

10.2.2 In the event of changed circumstances within the year (e.g. a doctor leaving and a delay in their replacement), then team job planning may be revisited and a revised amount of measurable activity agreed.
The Job plan
10.3.1 All job plans will be based on the principles agreed within the Job Plan Policy.
10.3.2 An individual job plan should set out everything a doctor does in a ‘typical' working week, including private practice, ensuring that no activity is double counted.
10.3.3 The job plan must include non-working time following agreement under the relevant Trust policies or procedures.
10.3.4 Ensure that service development, education, training and research are recognised and supported where appropriate and allocated equitably.
Job Plan Objectives
10.4.1 Job planning should be focused on measurable outcomes that benefit patients and are consistent with the objectives of the NHS, the Trust, teams and individuals.
10.4.2 The objectives will:
10.4.3 Be SMART – Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Realistic and Timed
Reflect different, developing phases in the doctor's career
Be informed by team job planning and team objectives
Be agreed on the understanding that delivery of objectives may be affected by changes in circumstances or factors outside the doctor's control, which will be considered at the Job Plan review
Take account of any objectives agreed with other employers where relevant
Where a doctor has additional trust-approved SPAs or ANR PAs, e.g. Educational Supervisor, Appraiser, Clinical Lead, these PAs will carry separate agreed objectives for the role
10.4.4 The objectives will include:
Reflecting the current Trust, Divisional and Local service objectives based on team objectives and team working
Key Quality and Performance indicators
Management of resources, including efficient use of NHS and Trust resources
Service development
Additional responsibilities
10.4.5 Annualisation of DCC activity

10.4.6 DCC job plan components can be annualised and the Division should record the activity delivered. This includes individual activity and team based delivery of 52 weeks provision based on  weeks of availability.
10.4.7 These calculations are completed via the trust's job planning software, for example the provision of Emergency work on each Saturday of the year by 8 Consultants between 0900 and 1400:
52 / 8 = 6.5 Saturdays a year
5hrs / 3 = 1.67 PAs
6.5 /  weeks = 0.26 PAs a week

10.4.8 Timetables will cover a week, but can be extended to cover a number of weeks (e.g. where activities vary from week to week) or commitments may be annualised (e.g. for doctors working flexibly whose activities may vary at different times of the year) where agreed between the doctor and the Trust.
10.4.9 For planning purposes annualised job plans will be based on an assumption of 42 weeks of clinical service, unless the consultant participates in hot week activity.
10.4.10 Example
10.4.11 in  hot activity, consultant will be committed to 5.2 weeks of hot activity per annum. Based on  weeks of attendance this will equate to 36.8 weeks of routine activity.

10.4.12 This assumes six weeks leave and 2 days of statutory leave (converted into annual leave allowance), 8 public holidays and  days of study/ professional leave. Annual leave carry over is subject to the trust's annual leave policy.
10.4.13 This calculation will be pro rata for those with increased annual leave due to seniority (7 years as a consultant).

10.4.14 In other cases there may be periods of sick leave, unpaid leave, parental leave etc. When the organisation monitors the delivery of job plans, the additional unplanned leave must be taken into account as  weeks will not be applicable in these situations.
10.4.15 Some consultants take fewer days of leave particularly study/professional leave dependent on their professional development requirements in the 3 year cycle.

10.4.16 If taking  days study leave in a year these days are outside of the 42 job planned weeks. If study leave is on a non-working day, this time off has already been provided within the time outside of the 42 weeks.

10.4.17 However if a consultant is for example in year 1 of the 3 year study leave cycle and takes 5 days study leave (intending to take  in year 2), they will need 5 additional days out of their job planned DCC in year
The Job Planning Process
The clinician will meet with their Clinical Manager and if in agreement the Service Manager to discuss and agree the job plan either unchanged or incorporating any agreed changes.

If the clinician is not in agreement with the service manager attending, arrangements will be made for the job planning meeting to either proceed with the Clinical Manager on a one to one basis if both parties are in agreement or for the Consultant to bring a workplace colleague or LNC representative.

If agreement cannot be reached within a reasonable timeframe (usually 4 weeks from when the consultant or manager states they are unable to agree the proposed job plan), then the job planning process must be referred for mediation. The Clinical Director will send both the doctor and the Mediator a letter setting out the nature of the dispute within 6 weeks of the original meeting.

Job plans for newly appointed substantive or locum posts should reflect the job plan agreed in the job description. The Clinical Manager should ensure that a job plan review takes place within 3 months of the doctor taking up the post, and thereafter annual reviews should take place as usual.

In accordance with national terms and conditions of service, where a job plan is in dispute, no changes will be made to the job plan until the disputes procedures have been exhausted. If, however a doctor, after reasonable notice and support, fails to engage in a job plan review when requested by their manager to do, any temporary additional PAs previously agreed will not automatically be renewed, but may be withdrawn and pay appropriately adjusted until the matter is resolved.

If, despite being given reasonable notice and opportunity, a doctor fails to attend a job planning meeting requested by their Clinical Manager within a reasonable period of time (usually four weeks unless exceptional circumstances apply), they will be held to be in breach of this policy.
Capacity Lists and other Capacity work

Consultants are often asked to perform additional lists, clinics, investigations or reports in order to reduce or maintain patient waiting times. One of the important principles of the 2003 Consultant Contract is that Consultants cannot be paid twice for the same period of time. For this reason, Consultants must not, under any circumstances, undertake ‘waiting list (time) initiative' lists or other capacity work whilst on- call. The Trust will not, under any circumstances, ask Consultants to undertake lists or other related work whilst on-call.

The Trust will not normally ask Consultants to perform non job planned activities work during their SPA time. Any DCC activity that may displace SPA allocated time should only take place after agreement with the doctor and where possible with adequate notice. When this occurs, the displaced SPA should be allocated at another time and there should be explicit written agreement regarding the time and location of this (normally within 6 weeks). This does not apply in circumstances such as a National pandemic, please refer to 4.8.

Where it is agreed that the displaced SPA will be performed in lieu of a clinical session, the Consultant will not be entitled to any additional remuneration for the additional sessional work undertaken. In contrast, where it has been agreed that the displaced SPA will be performed at a time when the Consultant is not contracted to work for the Trust the Consultant will be entitled to payment for the non- job planned activity work at rates at least equivalent to the rates of standard time as defined by the national terms and conditions.

If there is a request for a doctor to cover DCC in SPA time to cover unexpected unplanned emergencies e.g. sick leave of a colleague the SPA time will be repaid back at a mutually agreed time (normally within 6 weeks). This will not normally attract enhanced payment.
Leave
Please refer to the Leave Policy.
Locums

The Trust will agree job plans with locums as per this policy if appointed to positions of 12 months or more and will take into account their familiarity with Trust systems and processes and the extent to which their contribution may differ from their colleagues.

The job plan may differ from the Consultant they are replacing and they may deliver more direct clinical care. The Trust standard core SPA allocation will apply to locum doctors to enable them to meet college and other external requirements.
Job Plan Sign-off Process

All staff involved in job planning process have a responsibility to ensure sign off process is managed in a timely manner. Doctors must fully co-operate with Trust job planning processes in line with contractual requirements. It is recognised sign off of the job plan falls outside of the consultant's control, please see Appendix
First sign-off

15.3.1 The draft Job Plan will be reviewed and agreed by the Consultant or SAS Doctor and their Clinical Lead and service manager using e-job planning. Once agreed the doctor will submit their job plan and this will lead to provisional 1st sign-off. This applies to all doctors, including clinical leads, clinical directors and divisional directors. If there is no clinical lead (or if the doctor is the clinical lead), the clinical director should provide the 1st sign-off. If there is no clinical director (or if the doctor is the clinical director) or clinical lead, an alternative clinical director from another clinical area should be used for 1st sign-off.
15.3.2 There will be demonstration of adherence to budget and job planning principles, including the following list:
Confirm budget approval

Confirm DCCs are consistent with service needs. The sum total of individual DCCs for consultant and SAS doctors should not exceed the sum total of service DCCs. For example, the sum total of anaesthesia DCCs should equate to the sum total of DCCs for anaesthetists taking into account the 42-week plan and services delivered by non-consultant-non-SAS doctors
Confirm SPA
Second sign-off:
15.4.1 The Clinical Director / Divisional Medical Director will review and agree the Job Plan on the allocate system for 2nd sign-off
15.4.2 The Clinical Director / Divisional Medical director will return the job plan back via allocate to the discussion stage if principles have not been adhered to as per 14.1.
Third sign-off:
15.5.1 The Divisional Medical Director will review and agree the Job Plan on the allocate system for 3rd sign-off ensuring that job plans are aligned to service delivery and within budget envelope.

15.5.2 Following final sign off the Group Clinical Director will instruct the Service Manager or equivalent to complete payroll paperwork as necessary (to the nearest 0.25 PA) following an increase or decrease in job planned activity.
Annual Job Planning Timetable
15.6.1  Job planning will take place on an annual cycle for each doctor, please see Appendix
Job Plan Reviews
15.7.1 A Job Plan will usually be reviewed on an annual basis as part of the Trust wide job planning round.

15.7.2 However there may be times during the year when changes occur and a Consultant or SAS Doctor's Job Plan will need to be reviewed, either due to external influences having an impact on the service which the Consultant or SAS Doctor provides or because a Consultant or SAS Doctor circumstances have changed. For example where activity in a department has either increased or decreased, or the local Clinical Commissioning Group contracts for particular services have changed, Job Plans will need to be reviewed and amended accordingly to meet the needs of the service.
Job Planning and the link to Clinical Excellence Awards

15.8.1  It has been determined nationally that adherence to the National Standards of Best Practice for Job Planning will form part of the eligibility criteria for clinical excellence awards. The Trust expects all Consultants who apply for a Clinical Excellence Award to have participated fully in job planning for the relevant year. The sign off process is outside of the consultants control as such there should be no detriment to any consultant who has co-operated fully with the job planning process.
Job Plan Appeals Process

15.9.1 Where it has not been possible to agree a Job Plan or a Consultant or SAS Doctor disputes a decision that he or she has not met the criteria required for pay progression in a given year, a mediation process and appeal procedure is available

15.9.2 Full details of the mediation process and appeal procedure are outlined in Schedule 4 of the Terms and Conditions which can be found on the NHS Employers website. The link can be found in the references section.
15.9.3 Appendix 5
Audit of Job Planning Process

15.10.1  In the spirit of openness and transparency the Trust will make available to the Trust Board, LNC, MAC and Management Team, data regarding the outcome of the Job Planning process on an annual basis.
Job Plan Committee – NHSi Attainment

15.11.1  The trust will work in collaboration with the LNC to form a Job Planning Committee. It is envisaged that the Committee will undertake an annual review of a sample of signed-off job plans from Divisions. The purpose of this is to ensure consistency and application of this policy.
Monitoring compliance
In order to ensure compliance with this policy, the Trust will undertake the following monitoring

table_items.text: Signed off job plans to meet Requirements Of commissioners and the Trust
Clinical leads, clinical directors, divisional directors, service managers, ADOs

Department of Health, A Code of Conduct for Private Practice, Recommendations and Standards of Practice for NHS Consultants. BMA/NHS Employers nationally agreed ‘A practical guide to calculating on-call work
Allocate Consultant and SAS Guide: https://products.zircadian.com/ConsultantsUI/Documents/Doctor_guide_for_eJobPla n_England.pdf
Allocate Management Guide: https://products.zircadian.com/ConsultantsUI/Documents/Manager_guide_for_eJobP lan_England.pdf
Appendix 1: Detailed definitions of PAs
Detailed definitions of PAs – direct clinical care (DCC), supporting professional activities (SPA), additional NHS responsibilities (ANR), external duties (ED) and emergency work .
Direct Clinical Care (DCC)
Only activity which has been commissioned from the Trust will be included in the allocation of Direct Clinical Care (DCC) to individual team members.

There will be minimum standards for activity expected by individuals within the particular specialty e.g. number of new and follow up out patients to be seen in outpatient clinics, number of operations to be completed in a theatre session etc. These will be agreed with the doctors at team job planning.
Programmed Activities (PAs) and the appropriate availability supplement will be allocated for the predictable and unpredictable work performed whilst on call.
Compensatory rest will be in line with T&Cs.

Clinical administration will be linked to DCC activities and will be agreed in each Division. Clinical administration time is 0.25 per 1PA DCC Clinic and should be clearly defined within job planning. It is recognised that some specialties are admin intensive and any requirements for additional admin should be consistent within the specialty and agreed with the Clinical Lead / Director.
Teaching during a DCC activity runs concurrently
Supporting Professional Activities (SPAs)

Supporting Professional Activities (SPA) form a core part of a Consultant or SAS Doctor's work and are essential to ensure that a Consultant or SAS Doctor keeps up to date, maintains training requirements and revalidates. SPAs are not optional and are a required part of the job plan.
SPA should be scheduled in the job plan and take place during core hours or as agreed with permitted flexibility as in section 7.3 of main document
There should be objectives for SPA – Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Realistic, and Timed (SMART).
It is expected that SPA time should predominately consist of:
Core SPAs, which are self-directed activities associated to one's own practice. These activities include those required for:
Additional NHS Responsibilities (ANR)

There are a range of additional NHS responsibilities that Consultants undertake both within the Trust and externally which the Trust recognises and supports. These responsibilities relate to specific roles filled by clinicians for a defined period, and these activities will have allocated ANR PAs. Regional or national educational roles are covered by ANR.
The nature of the additional responsibility and the time required to fulfil it should be discussed and agreed with the Clinical Manager prior to the commencement of the activtiy.

Appropriate funding must be identified for research that is approved by the Research and Development department, or other recognised research bodies and prior to commencement agreed with the Clinical Manager.
Any SPA time above the core SPA allowance which is allocated for specific activities will need be mapped to the specific funding (budget) and agreed with the Clinical Manager prior to commencement.

When the Consultant is paid ANR PAs by an external organisation, there is no requirement to allocate PAs to discharge this responsibility however the nature of the additional responsibility should be noted in the Job Plan and adequate time identified.
Examples of Additional NHS Responsibilities include:
Medical managerial leadership: Medical Director, Divisional Director, Clinical Director or Clinical Lead
Director of Public Health
Caldicott Guardian
Governance: clinical audit lead or other governance activity
Regional or national educational roles: Undergraduate Dean, Postgraduate Dean, clinical tutor, regional education advisor and others
Responsible Officer
Appraiser or appraisal lead role
Guardian of Safe Working
Trade Union Responsibilities
Speciality Leads
Educational Supervisors
Clinical Supervisor
Additional Programmed Activities (APA)

Additional PAs are not linked to spare professional capacity but may be used to reflect regular, additional duties or activities (whether scheduled or unscheduled) that cannot be contained within a standard ten PA contract. They can be used, for example, to recognise an unusually high routine workload, or to recognise additional responsibilities. In this context “regular” is not intended to necessarily imply “at the same time each week or month”. The terms and conditions provide flexibility for employers and consultants to agree to contract for additional PAs for a variety of purposes, although no consultant or Speciality doctor can be compelled to agree to a contract containing more than 10 PAs.

Additional Programmed Activities (APAs) are all PAs beyond 10. APAs are temporary and will be formally reviewed as part of the annual job plan review and may be introduced or reduced subject to no fewer than three months in advance of the start of the proposed extra Programmed Activities, or six months in advance where the work would mean the consultant has to re-schedule external commitments (which can be waived by mutual agreement). APAs may consist of DCC, SPAs, additional NHS responsibilities and/or any other external duties.

Additional Programmed Activities may be offered on a fixed basis, but where possible the employing organisation will offer them on a mutually agreed annualised basis. Where consultants prospectively agree to extra Programmed Activities these will be remunerated.

Where more than 10PAs are included in a job plan there will be a clear distinction between the baseline PAs (those included in the 10 PA total which forms the permanent part of the doctors job) and APA

There will be a minimum notice period of three months for termination of these additional activities. If a consultant ceases to undertake Private Professional Services, he/she may relinquish the additional Programmed Activity subject to a similar notice period;
General Teaching Commitments

Clinicians are expected to participate in education as part of their employment; it is considered part of core DCC. It is important to recognise that time spent teaching in clinics and ward rounds already described in job plan is not additional.

Undergraduate teaching relates to specific undergraduate teaching in SPA time and is separate from contact time during fixed activities such as clinics. The amount of SPA time for this activity will be individually agreed as part of the job planning process with the involvement of the division and the undergraduate department for education through an evidenced based approach.
APA and Private Practice – Extra Capacity

Extra PAs are referred to in Schedule 6 (consultants) and Schedule 7 (Speciality Doctors) of the Terms and Conditions and as those that are linked to spare professional capacity. Consultants and Speciality doctors wishing to undertake private practice as defined, and who wish to remain eligible for pay progression, are required to offer up the first portion of any spare professional capacity (up to a maximum of one PA per week).

Where a consultant / speciality doctor intends to undertake such work, the employing organisation may, but is not obliged to, offer the consultant the opportunity to carry out up to one extra PA per week on top of the standard commitment set out in their contract of employment. The relevant schedule in the Terms and Conditions sets out the provisions regarding putting offers to consultants and the periods of notice required.

There is flexibility to agree a fixed number of extra PAs to be undertaken as required over the course of the year and NHS organisations may find this provision particularly helpful in that arrangements can be tailored to reflect varying service needs. One approach, for example, is to assess on a departmental basis how many extra PAs are likely to be required during the course of a year to increase capacity temporarily, for example for waiting list work; to cover clinics and lists; or to cover a vacancy. The employer can then contract for an agreed number of extra PAs with those consultants willing to work them.
External Duties (ED)

Some clinicians undertake additional duties for organisations which are associated with the NHS but not formally part of it. Some examples include college work and examinations, national representation on committees and teaching or external lectures.

Consultants who wish to perform external duties must seek formal agreement from their Divisional Director and ADO prior to applying for the role. The Trust will take a pragmatic approach to this decision on an individual basis and in principle agree to support external duties so long as:

There is demonstrable benefit to the individual, the Trust or the wider NHS The clinical lead, clinical director, divisional director and ADO support the request and support will not be unreasonably withheld. There is no significant loss of service delivery within the specialty/department unless replacement of this loss is agreed by the divisional director and ADO
Where Consultants are already performing external duties, the nature of these and the time commitment associated with the duties will be reviewed as part of the annual Job Plan review.
Examples of External Duties include:
Calculating On Call Availability Supplement (OCAS) for Mixed Frequency or Category Rotas
This appendix outlines how these examples may be worked through and agreed but the final decision will rest with Job Planning Committee and subject to the Appeals
process.
Example for mixed frequency rota for job plan:

If doctors participate in two rotas, they do not normally receive the supplement for each. Normally, the overall on-call commitment or frequency would be calculated to establish the true frequency. This is a relatively easy process IF the rotas are in the same category.
e.g.
1:18 Cat A = 2.89 weeks of on call per annum - 3% if only rota 1:4 Cat A = 13 weeks of on-call per annum - 8% if only rota
Total = 15.29 weeks = 1in 3.4 = 8% OCAS i.e. doctor does not receive 11% (3+8)
Examples for a mixed category rota for job plan:
If the rotas are in different categories, the TCS does not cover this and OCAS will have to be determined by local agreement.
The Trust approach will be based on the assumption that no clinician will receive more than 8% for their on-call supplement.
If a doctor participates in two rotas, one of which is in Category A High Frequency, an 8% on-call supplement will be allocated.

If a doctor participates in two rotas with different categories, and neither of the rotas are in the  Category  A  High  banding,  the  supplement  allocated,  will  be  the  full  value  of  the Category A rota, plus the half value of the Category B rota.
Appendix 2: Agreed standard Trust travel times

The table below sets out the agreed standard Trust travel times for common journeys between sites made by Consultants or SAS Doctors employed by the Trust. These times have been compiled from responses to the LNC's survey in July 2020. For any frequent journeys not included in this table please use the time from Google Maps.

Travel times should be monitored and reviewed with the participation of Consultants and SAS doctors. All travel time should include the time taken to travel from one site to another “door to door” this would take account of normal levels of traffic including variations in traffic at different times of day, the time to park and any journey necessary on foot rounded up to the nearest 15 minutes. All travel time between clinics is working time and should be accounted for fully in the job plan.
E-Job planning will not allow for specific times to be entered as it counts in 15 minute multiples.
Appendix 3: Annual Job Planning Cycle

table_items.text: Clinical director sends out preparation for and invitation to job plan review, with preparation guidelines, giving six weeks' notice.

Team job planning meeting to discuss and agree objectives, supporting professional activities list and any required rota changes. Individual job planning meetings take place. Job plans entered on electronic job planning system by 31 December. This allows three months for the mediation/appeals process.
Quarter 4 – January to March the following year
Mediation and/or appeals completed as soon as possible, in line with the timeframe agreed under the 2003 consultant contract. (or SAS contract 2008)
Quarter 1 – April to June the following year
Job plan effective 1 April. Mandatory training to begin for the year

Preparation:
Consultant or SAS Doctor prepares Job Plan and seeks help from service manager if required
st Sign-off (provisional):
Clinical Lead with Service Manager
nd Sign-off: Clinical Director
rd Sign-off Group Clinical Director
Change form completed by service. Approved by the budget holder and by finance. This is submitted to Transactional team (ESR)
for processing amendment to pay.
Sign Off for Job Plan Changes Outside Job Planning Cycle

N.B. Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust recognises that job plans for Consultants and SAS doctors may need to be changed outside of the formal job planning business cycle for a number of valid reasons.
